passageHtml: Researchers from NASA and the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory had long wanted to test Einstein’s equivalence principle, which stated that the observed equivalence of inertial mass and gravitational mass is an effect of nature. The researchers set out to substantiate this theory. To do this, the researchers launched Gravity Probe A (GP-A), a hydrogen maser, into space to determine how time passes in a location with weak gravitational pull. The probe was launched from Virginia in 1976 and stayed in space for just under two hours before crashing back to Earth in the Atlantic Ocean. The researchers determined that the data collected by GP-A supported Einstein’s equivalent principle.

passageHtml:
The following text is adapted from O. Henry’s 1905 short story “The Gift of the Magi.” A married couple is trying to buy sentimental Christmas gifts for each other despite not having much money to spend on them.

One dollar and eighty-seven cents. That was all. And sixty cents of it was in pennies. Pennies saved one and two at a time by bulldozing the grocer and the vegetable man and the butcher until one's cheeks burned with the silent imputation of parsimony that such close dealing implied. Three times Della counted it.

passageHtml: A field of intriguing possibilities, space tourism has attracted the attention of entrepreneurs looking to offer their clients the next phase of leisure travel. In response, aerospace researchers often call attention to the challenges of humans living in space for extended periods of time. Primarily, extended periods of low gravity as well as the visual uniformity of empty space put a strain on the physical and mental capabilities of humans, forcing a need for various and significant diversions to be present, which further complicates the design of a potential leisure spacecraft. Although the challenges are many, a subset of aerospace researchers known as aerospace architects seek to address these concerns and make space travel a possibility for a greater percentage of the population.

passageHtml: To better honor the diverse cultural groups that call Papua New Guinea home, Jayawijaya Regent John Wempi Wetipo commissioned the Rumah Nusantara House, a museum in the region of Wamena. One of the items Wetipo and his staff have on display in the museum is a noken, a traditional entwined or plaited bag from Indonesia used to carry a wide variety of items and even young children. It is often hung from the head and carried by women in the Western New Guinea region. The noken is often used in political settings as a collection box for voting ballots and has been praised as a symbol to bridge the gap between competing tribes in the area.

passageHtml: Pansori, a genre of storytelling used in Korea, blends vocal performance with percussive instruments. The nineteenth century is often called the golden age of pansori, when its musical techniques became more advanced and attracted the attention of upper-class patrons. However, evidence for the elite’s appreciation of the music genre appears even earlier in recorded history. Many music historians note that while eighteenth-century pansori street performances attracted large audiences of lower-class citizens, members of the Korean nobility would attend these performances as well.

passageHtml: Selective breeding is the process by which individuals with desirable characteristics—such as robust health or docile temperament—are bred together in the hopes of passing on these attributes to their offspring. In an experiment, researcher Lyudmila Trut sought to discover how selective breeding transforms species during domestication. She observed a group of docile foxes who were already in captivity and allowed them to breed with limited human interaction, with the goal of determining if the docile behavior exhibited by these foxes was due to genetics or prior human training. Trut claimed that the offspring were tame due to genetics, and selective breeding had caused the trait to be passed down to each subsequent group of fox offspring.

questionText: Which quotation from a paper published by a fellow researcher who analyzed the same group of docile foxes best supports Trut’s claim?

A.text: “The fox group here was larger than the ones I had observed in the past, and this created more opportunities for conflict. I observed some dominant tendencies in this fox group that smaller fox groups don’t always display.”

A

A

fullHtml: Selective breeding is the process by which individuals with desirable characteristics—such as robust health or docile temperament—are bred together in the hopes of passing on these attributes to their offspring. In an experiment, researcher Lyudmila Trut sought to discover how selective breeding transforms species during domestication. She observed a group of docile foxes who were already in captivity and allowed them to breed with limited human interaction, with the goal of determining if the docile behavior exhibited by these foxes was due to genetics or prior human training. Trut claimed that the offspring were tame due to genetics, and selective breeding had caused the trait to be passed down to each subsequent group of fox offspring.

The following text is from Hilda Doolittle’s 1916 poem “Storm.”

You crash over the trees,
you crack the live branch—
the branch is white,
the green crushed,
each leaf is rent like split wood.

You burden the trees
with black drops,
you swirl and crash—
you have broken off a weighted leaf
in the wind,
it is hurled out,
whirls up and sinks,
a green stone.

passageHtml:
Text 1

The United States is one of three nations that do not predominantly use the metric system today. Despite efforts in the 1970s, the US was unable to convert its preferred system of measurements to metric. With the world becoming more integrated, it is time for the US to adopt metric as its primary system of measurements. Because the current system in the US does not rely on a consistent numerical factor such as the ten used by the metric system, it is far more prone to miscalculation during unit conversions.

Text 2

While most of the world uses the metric system, the US has the flexibility of keeping its current system while using the metric system on a voluntary basis. Measurements based on everyday things, such as the foot measured in relation to the human body, make sense to people. Still, there are many opportunities to include both systems, such as showing both miles and kilometers on speedometers.

passageHtml: Bees are able to distinguish flowers from other objects not only by their colors and odors but also by their electrical field strengths. Field researchers noted that bees were unlikely to land on a flower for about 20 minutes after it had been sprayed with fertilizer. A team of scientists led by Dr. Ellard Hunting explored whether charged particles in fertilizers affected the electrical fields of flowers and whether altered electrical fields changed bee behavior. In an experiment, the scientists sprayed cut flowers with fertilizer, measured the electrical field strength around the flowers, and observed bee behavior around the electrically-manipulated flowers. The team concluded that fertilizer affected the electrical field strength of flowers and caused bees to avoid fertilized flowers.

In an experiment, the scientists sprayed cut flowers with fertilizer, measured the electrical field strength around the flowers, and observed bee behavior around the electrically-manipulated flowers. The team concluded that fertilizer affected the electrical field strength of flowers and caused bees to avoid fertilized flowers.

The team concluded that fertilizer affected the electrical field strength of flowers and caused bees to avoid fertilized flowers. passageHtml: Immediately following the Big Bang, the lightest elements, such as lithium, helium, and hydrogen, were produced. Other, heavier elements—such as iron—were formed over time in the cores of stars. The origin of these heavier elements has perplexed scientists for decades. It has been theorized that the rapid absorption of neutrons (known as r-process) releases these heavier elements into space. Following a collision of two dead stars, an event that involves extremely rapid rates of neutron absorption, astrophysicist Darach Watson and colleagues expected to observe the release of at least some of the heavier elements. They were surprised, however, to detect the presence of only strontium, one of the lightest heavy elements in existence.

passageHtml:
The following text is adapted from Thomas Mann’s 1924 novel The Magic Mountain. In the novel, protagonist Hans Castorp visits his cousin, who has tuberculosis, at a sanatorium in the Swiss mountains.

The pity the well person felt for the sick—a pity that almost amounted to awe, because the well person could not imagine how he himself could possibly bear such suffering—was very greatly exaggerated. The sick person had no real right to it. It was, in fact, the result of an error in thinking, a sort of hallucination; in that the well man attributed to the sick his own emotional equipment, and imagined that the sick man was, as it were, a well man who had to bear the agonies of a sick one—than which nothing was further from the truth.

passageHtml:
Text 1

Some scholars argue that because humans were likely at least in part responsible for the extinction of the woolly mammoth, scientists should try to bring this species back. Geneticist George Church has made 15 genetic alterations to elephant genes to render them more mammoth-like. Church and others argue that reintroducing the mammoth could improve the biodiversity of arctic ecosystems that have been impacted by the effects of climate change.

Text 2

Paleobiologist Tori Herridge notes that Asian elephants and mammoths are no more related than are chimpanzees and humans and that a surrogate elephant mother could face serious health challenges were a genetically altered elephant embryo to be implanted inside her. She further contends that there are more straightforward ways to combat climate change and adds that bringing back species could reintroduce to the world diseases that would threaten livestock or humans.

passageHtml: Organisms usually require a brain and nervous system to coordinate their movements. According to a study led by biochemist Wallace Marshall, though, a single-celled organism called Euplotes eurystomus can apparently walk using a simple, mechanical processor. The protozoan E. eurystomus has 14 clusters of cilia, which are hair-like structures controlled by a series of internal connections. Disruptions in these connections can cause malfunctions, such as circular movements rather than the intended linear direction observed under normal conditions.
